content:
The constraints are very misleading here.
All of your answers are between 1 and 80.
You could code this very easily by simply searching from 1 to 99 for an 'x' that evaluates the statement as true in shortest mode.
You should at least have a negative x and an x with magnitude greater than 1000 in both a test case and a validator, or simply reduce the huge variable space and change validator 5 to match.
The large variable space makes this problem seem much harder than it is.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like equation and I very like this

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not many like this in Clash of Code right now
Was fun, solvable
I think the question is easy to understand.

The test cases are simply not exhaustive enough, I passed all of them but when inputting my own equations I could find plenty of flaws in my code that made it a very broken equation solver.

For instance, not a single test case contains a multiplication on the right-hand side.
Also, as mentioned by someone else, the unknown only appears on the left-hand side. The constraints are kind of lying regarding that aspect, implying the x could take the spot of any number.

Incidentally, this also makes the provided solution broken, for example it fails to solve this equation: 5-x=9+2
Expected: -6, Actual: 16

Which also makes me notice I don't ever see a negative x as output in tests, despite the constraints which imply that x can take a negative value.

Turns out that a fully working solution isn't a pretty trivial one to write. It'd take me well beyond the CoC time duration to do that.

Also the provided solution is based on "eval" which isn't a facility available in all languages.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Suffisamment difficile pour ne pas être résolu en 2 secondes mais super facile à comprendre !
How about sth like "2x=10"?
cute profile picture
If x is an integer then you should write -(2^31) ≤  number ≤ (2^31)-1.

- You should add spaces between number, operator and =, to help parsing of data.
- Test coverage is low : you never test when x is on the right side of the equation
- Validator should match tests, with only numbers that change.
- Reverse mode will be very hard without the constraint on x, you should remove it
Test 3 is not correct.
please put a lower bound for x, even if it is 0.
I think the question is very simple but the solution is not too easy to code. Besides, all three game modes fit very well, including reverse. I would approve it. :)
that also means your solution is not correct.
I think that it is the right way to solve this challenge : use the low range on x to test all possiblities and easily solve a complex problem
You speak very definitely. These are all opinions none of these are based on any standards of CG. I disagree with all of this information you’ve said here.
Fixed
Initially, the restrictions stated that X cannot be negative. But then I was told that if X is a number, then you need to specify -2^31 ≤ X ≤ 2^31-1.
Yes, it's slightly upsetting that this got accepted in this state. Makes we wonder whether the people that approved the contribution really bothered looking into it.

Correct, I see the comment, however I think the person made the distinction between integers and *unsigned* integers, the latter being strictly positive. However it's just semantics at this point, x is never seen negative so the constraint makes so sense in my opinion.

Sorry for your disagreement, but :
- I was asked to add spaces for the same reason, on a clash I submit recently. It was a good idea, not to take time in parsing entry. Parsing is so boring
- validators must match the tests, it is in the rules
- other comments said that the clash is too hard if not solved by bruteforce, this is the reason of my last comment

my bash answer :

expr=`sed s/=/==/`
for x in $(seq 1 100) $(seq -100 0); do
test $(( "$expr" )) -ne 0 && echo $x
done

passes all tests, but not validator 3, because this case is not tested in tests

2. Test 5.
3. Ok I can change validator 2, 3 and 4.
4. This can be solved without eval by checking all signs
Feels like cheating to me, also eval exists in very few languages.
Agree for eval, but almost everybody knows some python bases. For people that don't already know, they can discover it at the end of a challenge, by reading challenger's code.
This isn’t how clash works at all. BUT you can still solve this in any language with a good understanding.
Fixed
Does not work with  Test3
How are you going to say that??? Did you test my code in IDE? I did and it passed all tests and validators?!?

you should try again :

ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
at <string>. not in a function on line 1
at Answer.py. in <module> on line 3

a try /except: pass is needed
I guess I provably did have exception handling built in and left it out. I understand your point about test 3 vs validator 3. It’s a valid point
